 north-east of Kalgoorlie.

Soil sampling undertaken by Mt Kersey Mining NL returned anomalous Ni values of up to 
 2000 ppm within an ultramafic unit in the project area. 
 Conclusion:  Further exploration is planned to fully assess the potential of the project.

text:
(Roberts,  F.I.  et  al,  2000).  Gold  mineralisation  is  in  a  steeply  east  dipping  and  eastyounging, 
 northerly to north-northwesterly striking sequence of mafic rocks dominated by metamorphosed 
 tholeiitic basalt with lesser amounts of metadolerite. A north-northwesterly striking, east-dipping 
 fault - Yerilla Fault lies about 1 km east of the main mine workings at Yerilla. Historic mine 
 workings are distributed intermittently in the footwall of the Yerilla Fault, from Westward Ho 
 in the south, to Friday Well in the north – a distance of almost 35 km. However, the main centre 
 of  production  was  near  Yerilla  Homestead,  where  about  35  kg  of  gold  have  been  produced, 
 mainly from within the oxidized zone. There was also soon deeplead activity in the vicinity of 
 the  Yerilla  King  deposit.  There  are  no  recent  commercial  operations  (other  than  small-scale 
 alluvial mining) in the Yerilla and Mount Remarkable mining areas, but a combined resource of 
 almost 1000kg of gold has been identified at Bull Terrier and Dingo. These deposits, which are

text:
have been in the pressure shadow of the pluton during east-west regional deformation, and would 
 therefore have been a domain of low mean stress. Other brittle host structures that dip 45o west 
 and  east  within  the  pluton  (Melba  and  West  Melba)  probably  formed  as  complimentary 
 fractures within the same stress regime. The Yerilla King deposit is a shear zone that dips 45o W, 
 within mafic rocks adjacent to the western margin of the pluton. This may be a similar structure 
 to that at Melba Reef, which has projected upwards into the country rock. The Queen of the 
 Earth  deposit  is  a  steep,  brittle-ductile  shear  zone  oriented  subparrallel  to  the  north-trending 
 margin of the northwestern corner of the granite intrusion. 
 This would have been a site of high shear strain during east-west compression. At Mount 
 Catherine, east of the Yerilla Fault, a prominent quartz blow is oriented 335o and dips steeply 
 northeast  within  metabasalts.  Mining  was  concentrated  along  a  zone  of  strong  ductile 
 deformation, several metres wide, adjacent to the vein, and in the margins of the vein itself. The 
 main workings appear to be in the hanging wall of the quartz vein. The Bull Terrier deposit is a 
 sub-vertical,  north-northeasterly  striking,  dextral,  brittle  fault  zone  in  the  McAuliffe  Well 
 Syenite. The granite pluton probably acted in a similar fashion to the one at Yerilla in creating a 
 local domain of stress heterogeneity with low mean stress in the syenite. Dextral movement on 
 the fault is characterised by a deep, brick-red colour that reflects hematitization. Ore zones are 
 further  characterised  by  the  destruction  of  amphibole,  and  the  addition  of  hematite,  biotite, 
 calcite  and  pyrite.  Mineralisation  is  associated  with  a  fault  that  trends  30o  and  dips  80o  SE  to 
 subvertical. Displacement of the contact between felsic syenite and more-mafic monzogabbroic 
 rocks indicates 180m of dextral movement on the mineralised fault. At the surface, the fault is

10.text: shaft extend over about 150 m on a subvertical, veined shear zone that trends 010o. The shear

18.text: The  Yerilla  Project  area  is  covered  extensively  by  a  thin  (1-2m)  layer  of  Quaternary

19.text: colluvium, eluvium and Tertiary limonite deposits. The colluvium and eluvium consists of red-

20.text: brown to buff silt, sand and gravel with quartz or ironstone pebble veneer, and mixed angular to

21.text: rounded rock fragments in loam. Tertiary limonite deposits consist of cemented ironstone gravels

22.text: and laterite. The regolith is shown in the Landsat TM image (Figure 4).

text:
shaft extend over about 150 m on a subvertical, veined shear zone that trends 010o. The shear 
 zone is up to about 1.5m wide and contains quartz veins that are up to 20cm wide, but most are 
 thinner. Gold has been mined from a kaolin zone containing sulphide and quartz stockwork on a 
 contact zone 1 to 1.5m in width between mafic extrusive and mafic intrusive rocks. Three main 
 auriferous horizons which dip steeply east (80o) have been outlined. 
 The  Yerilla  Project  area  is  covered  extensively  by  a  thin  (1-2m)  layer  of  Quaternary 
 colluvium, eluvium and Tertiary limonite deposits. The colluvium and eluvium consists of red-
 brown to buff silt, sand and gravel with quartz or ironstone pebble veneer, and mixed angular to 
 rounded rock fragments in loam. Tertiary limonite deposits consist of cemented ironstone gravels 
 and laterite. The regolith is shown in the Landsat TM image (Figure 4).

 Radiometric and Landsat data were processed to produce the individual multi-band datasets 
 required for band ratios.  Standard and enhanced ratios were completed.  Digital Terrain Model 
 data was integrated with the remote sensing data to provide regolith models.   
 This  geophysical  imagery  was  integrated  with  all  available  GIS,  geological  and  surface 
 geochemical data to enhance the interpretation process.

26.text: Mt  Kersey  Mining  NL’s  Yerilla  Gold  Explortaion  Project  (Open  File  Item  No.  12919)

27.text: covered  a  large  area  including  the  ground  now  covered  by  tenements  P31/1718  –  1719.

28.text: Exploration during 1997 – 1998 included RAB and Aircore drilling, however the holes did not

29.text: fall into the area covered by tenements P31/1718 – 1719. During 1998 – 1999 work completed

30.text: on Mt Kersey’s Yerilla Project included soil sampling over an area which included P31/1718 and

31.text: the western half of E31/1719. Soil sampling returned anomalous Ni (up to 2000 ppm) and Cu

32.text: values in the western half of P31/1718, associated with an east facing ultramafic unit (Figure 7).

33.text: Anomalous soil sample Au values in the order of +4ppb Au did not fall within the area covered

34.text: by P31/1718-1719, and were associated with historic workings.

text:
the  old  Westward  Ho  Mines  and  returned  a  peak  value  of  11m  @  2.46  g/t  Au,  which  was 
 possibly due to contamination. The other costeans returned small As anomalies but no significant 
 Au. Two RC holes were drilled adjacent to the Westward Ho shaft/ Well to test the ground to the 
 north and south. Best intercepts included: 
 1m @ 4.63 g/t Au (20 – 21m) 
 1m @ 5.07 g/t Au (27 – 28m) 
 1m @ 9.1 g/t Au (35 – 36 m) 
 1 m @ 9.61 g/t Au (58 – 59m) 
 Mt  Kersey  Mining  NL’s  Yerilla  Gold  Explortaion  Project  (Open  File  Item  No.  12919) 
 covered  a  large  area  including  the  ground  now  covered  by  tenements  P31/1718  –  1719. 
 Exploration during 1997 – 1998 included RAB and Aircore drilling, however the holes did not 
 fall into the area covered by tenements P31/1718 – 1719. During 1998 – 1999 work completed 
 on Mt Kersey’s Yerilla Project included soil sampling over an area which included P31/1718 and 
 the western half of E31/1719. Soil sampling returned anomalous Ni (up to 2000 ppm) and Cu 
 values in the western half of P31/1718, associated with an east facing ultramafic unit (Figure 7).   
 Anomalous soil sample Au values in the order of +4ppb Au did not fall within the area covered 
 by P31/1718-1719, and were associated with historic workings.
